strong_yes.headline: CEO @ Kode With Klossy; Product Leader; Advisor and Mentor; Voter and Poll Worker
strong_yes.summary:
I have spent my career working to support for-profit, nonprofit, philanthropic, and political organizations. Despite these very different contexts, the through line in my career has always been the transformative power of technology.

I am currently the inaugural CEO for the 501c3 nonprofit Kode with Klossy (KWK). KWK is a talent retention solution focused on closing the gender gap equity in tech. By providing ongoing technical learning experiences and curated opportunities, KWK supports a community of almost 11,000 young women and gender-expansive youth across their education and career milestones, from age 13 to 26.

Before KWK, I spent time in philanthropy as a Vice President of Technology and Head of Justice & Opportunity at the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative (CZI). CZI is a philanthropy that leverages technology to address systemic challenges and maximize social impact. Before CZI, I was the Chief Product Officer for the Hillary for America presidential campaign from launch day to election day. 

I started my career in the for-profit software industry. I spent 15+ years as a product leader in startup, mid-size, and large organizations with experience across both enterprise and consumer technology. My first role in product management was at a venture-backed collaboration software startup. Then, at eBay, I managed seller and trust & safety products for the marketplace. While at Google, I served in product roles for ad technology platforms like AdWords and Doubleclick.

strengths: Proven track record as CEO of a nonprofit focused on gender equity in tech.
Extensive experience in leveraging technology for social impact through philanthropy.
Strong community engagement with a network of 11,000 young women and gender-expansive youth.
gaps_or_concerns: Limited experience in large-scale fundraising compared to the budget size of Girls Who Code.
Needs to demonstrate broader national visibility beyond current role.

Osi's commitment to empowering young women in tech aligns perfectly with the mission of Girls Who Code. Her leadership experience and innovative mindset position her well to lead the organization through its current inflection point, ensuring continued growth and impact.

strong_yes.headline: CEO | Board Director | Mission-Driven Leader | Operationalizing Impact
strong_yes.summary:
Ahmad Thomas is the CEO of the Silicon Valley Leadership Group (SVLG), one of the nation’s most dynamic business associations representing the global technology companies driving the innovation economy and its ecosystem.

Thomas has catalyzed industry-leading initiatives to harness the potential of emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence, creating the Institute for California AI Policy (I-CAP) to help shape the regulatory posture needed to support its responsible development and further deployment. He has also focused efforts with global technology brands to operationalize change around inclusion and belonging, implementing a partnership strategy to diversify STEM talent pipelines by piloting a first-of-its-kind alliance with Historically Black Colleges and Universities. 

A former investment banker and senior Congressional aide, Thomas brings 20 years of experience working both in and on behalf of businesses, social enterprises, and governments, where he has honed a deep understanding of the essentiality of public-private partnerships and the intersection of equity, policy, and technology that drives Silicon Valley’s innovation infrastructure. 

He previously managed over $15 billion in public infrastructure, social impact, and development project offerings across multiple sectors including most notably executing the first ever Social Bonds issuance for a non-profit in the U.S. municipal bond market.

He serves on several boards aligned with his core passions around technology, sports and adventure, and helping underserved communities. Thomas has volunteered time in advisory roles at multiple start-up companies and was selected in 2023 as a “Top 50 Diverse Board Candidate” by the Nasdaq Center for Board Excellence and Equilar.

Thomas is a Life Member of the Council on Foreign Relations. He is an American Leadership Forum, Senior Fellow and is included in the Silicon Valley Business Journal "Power 100" - a list of the most influential people working in Silicon Valley today.

strengths: Proven track record in leading large-scale initiatives in technology and policy.
Strong commitment to equity and inclusion, evidenced by partnerships with HBCUs.
Extensive experience in stakeholder engagement and coalition building.
gaps_or_concerns: Limited direct experience in the education sector.
No specific background in youth-serving organizations.

strong_yes.headline: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER| Educational Nonprofits | Philanthropic Foundations | Edtech Startups | Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Thought Leader | Qualified Board Member I Social Impact Innovator I STEM Change Maker
strong_yes.summary:
HIGHEST OVERSIGHT: $35M+ P&L | 1,600 Team Members | Global Organization 

 LEADERSHIP VALUE & IMPACT
An energetic high-impact leader with 25+ years of demonstrated leadership experience in nonprofit executive leadership, business development, and K-12 and higher education. Possesses deep knowledge and experience leading business and nonprofit management, expanding fundraising networks, creating innovative programs, and facilitating multidimensional processes. 

Driven by passion as a deeply committed advocate of equitable educational opportunities for underserved populations, impacting the lives and careers of millions of children. Inclusion champion and influencer driving policy change at all levels to improve educational opportunities and equity justice while aligning organizational strategy and fostering a diverse, results-oriented team culture.

Sets a bold vision for the organization anchored in equity and social impact; builds a talented and diverse team; elevates solutions and ideas; and, in conjunction, creates a strategy that aligns the business, social impact, and diversity goals of the organization.

 25+ YEARS OF SOCIAL IMPACT LEADERSHIP HISTORY 
Social Impact Advisor to Google’s Impact and Outreach Team and transformational leadership at educational nonprofits, including Ada Developers Academy, Scratch Foundation, Duke Talent Identification Program (Duke TIP), MIT Introduction to Engineering and Science (MITES), and Broad Institute’s Diversity Initiative & Educational Outreach Program. 

•Quadrupled Scratch Foundation’s operational budget from $7M to $30M+ in 2 fiscal years, supporting the world’s largest coding platform serving 100M+ children worldwide. 
•Transformed Duke TIP, the largest academic talent search, with 450K+ students annually and 12K+ students matriculating through on-campus and online programs, into a social impact organization. 
•Spearheaded MITES programs at MIT and guided career trajectories of 3K+ next-generation STEM leaders from underrepresented and underserved communities by offering challenging, STEM-focused pre-college programs. 

 THOUGHT LEADERSHIP HIGHLIGHTS
•Women to Watch List 2022 – Sponsored by Nonprofit HR in recognition of contributions to the social impact sector.
•Champion for Black wealth creation w/ 500+ Black, intergenerational members through Onyx Black Wealth Collective. 
•Author – Published article in the Hechinger Report naming systemic injustices as “Opportunity Embargos” and advocated for equitable educational solutions to thwart negative impact of opportunity gaps on underserved children.

strong_yes.headline: Nonprofit Founder & CEO and Talent Nerd dedicated to ensuring the next generation of leaders emerges from everywhere
strong_yes.summary:
Aimée Eubanks Davis is the founder and CEO of Braven, a national nonprofit focused on ensuring that underrepresented college students are able to put their education to work and land strong first jobs upon graduation. Since 2013, Aimée has led a talented team of regional executive directors as well as the heads of product, technology, development, external affairs, and staff to ensure the best possible experience for Fellows. In partnership with university and employer partners, Braven is providing a systemic, sustainable, diverse talent strategy for our nation; to date, Braven has served more than 3,295 college students in Chicago, the Bay Area, Newark, New Jersey, New York City, and Atlanta. 

Prior to founding Braven, Aimée oversaw Teach For America's human capital and diversity initiatives for nearly a decade. During her tenure, she managed the human assets strategy for the organization’s 3,300+ full-time and seasonal staff and led the organization’s 130-person Human Assets function, which fueled the $300 million dollar organization’s growth and success.   

Aimée believes that the next generation of leaders will emerge from everywhere, which is also evident through her board membership with OneGoal, Relay Graduate School of Education, Education Pioneers, among others.

strong_yes.headline: Education Philanthropy, Investment, and Strategy
strong_yes.summary:
Nancy Lue is an entrepreneurial leader with over twenty years of experience as a strategist, operator, and investor and philanthropy leader in the education and social impact sectors. She has advised edtech companies and nonprofits on strategic planning, board governance, and creating scalable impact. Nancy currently leads the K-12 and data science education portfolios at the Valhalla Foundation and is also writing a book about the experiences and impact of first-generation college graduates.

She was a co-founder of the Advanced Education Research & Development Fund (AERDF), a collaboration  between the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation to dramatically accelerate innovations in learning. She previously served as Executive Director at the venture capital firm Global Silicon Valley (GSV) where she oversaw the launch of their edtech accelerator and the annual ASU GSV Summit. Prior to moving to Silicon Valley, Nancy served in the Obama Administration as a senior official at the U.S. Department of Education, where she led all of the federal agency’s strategic planning and performance management initiatives, including the development of its five-year strategic plan.  Nancy was previously a Principal at The Advisory Board Company where she led corporate strategy and new product development for the launch of the firm’s global higher education division, The Education Advisory Board (EAB). She also worked as Vice President of Strategic Planning for Edison Learning, the nation’s largest K12 education management company.  

Nancy has served on the governing boards, advisory committees, and appointed commissions of more than a dozen education organizations as well as a member of the Biden-Harris Education Transition Team. She is a current Pahara Fellow, a 2021 50CAN National Voices Fellow, a 2019 Presidential Leadership Scholar, a 2018 Silicon Valley Woman of Influence, and a Senior Fellow with the American Leadership Forum-Silicon Valley.

strong_yes.headline: Co-Founder, CEO @ Riipen | Bringing Real World Experience into the Classroom to Eliminate Underemployment | World’s Largest Experiential Learning Marketplace
strong_yes.summary:
We bridge the gap between education and meaningful careers.

I am the Co-Founder and CEO of Riipen, leading the world’s largest online work-based learning platform and ecosystem, connecting employers, academic institutions, and workforce development partners. Our mission is to close the skills gap, reduce underemployment, and drive state-wide adoption through strategic partnerships with consortiums and state-level initiatives.

At Riipen, we are committed to:

- Providing a platform where over 41,000 businesses and nonprofits can post work-based projects, making it easier for educators to bring meaningful experiential learning to their students.
- Helping students bridge the notorious experience gap that often hinders career advancement post-graduation, by offering them opportunities to demonstrate their skills to potential employers through tangible projects.

Here’s how we make a difference:

- Since our inception in 2013, Riipen has facilitated over 149,000 students from 680+ post-secondary institutions in gaining valuable, applied learning experiences that directly contribute to their professional growth.
- Our state-of-the-art technology ensures that both organizations and academic institutions find matching needs effortlessly, supporting our original goal of enhancing student development and career readiness.

A little bit about my journey to starting Riipen:

Inspired by personal challenges faced during my time at the University of Victoria, where I aimed to graduate debt-free, I experienced firsthand the difficulties of transitioning from education to a relevant career. This led me to envision and launch Riipen.

Prior to Riipen, my roles in B2B/B2C sales and marketing provided me with insights into the operational needs of growing organizations, fueling my drive to innovate in the education and recruitment sectors.

More about my personal life:

A native of Vancouver, BC, I’m an avid snowboarder, surfer, and world traveler. Whether catching waves, hitting the slopes, or competing in spike ball, I'm always on the move.

If you're an educator, student, or business leader looking to engage with the future of experiential learning, or if you're passionate about solving the challenge of underemployment, let’s connect.

strong_yes.headline: Founder & CEO at TalkingPoints - we're hiring!
strong_yes.summary:
Founder and CEO of TalkingPoints: www.talkingpts.org

TED talk: The most powerful yet overlooked resource in schools
https://go.ted.com/heejaelim

About TalkingPoints: 
TalkingPoints is an award-winning education technology non-profit with a mission to drive student success by unlocking the potential of families to fuel their children’s learning, especially in under-resourced communities. TalkingPoints multilingual family engagement platform connects and empowers families and teachers by using human and AI-powered, two-way translated communication and personalized content. This unique approach eliminates barriers including language, time, mindsets, and capacity to foster strong family engagement in development of students’ academic success.

Since its launch in 2015, TalkingPoints is supporting millions of educators and families each year across North America, and has been recognized with awards from Common Sense Education (2021 Best Overall Family Communication Platform), Google (Artificial Intelligence Challenge) and MIT and Stanford University. 

About Heejae: 
Heejae founded TalkingPoints based on her personal experience growing up as a Korean immigrant student and seeing her mother be able to make a difference in her education because she had the ‘voice’ to do so. Previously, Heejae worked on education reform to drive data-driven decision-making for public schools in the Middle East and served as chief of staff to a special advisor to the Secretary of Education in the UK. Heejae also worked on the development of Aspire Public Schools’ teacher training program, which is now Alder Education. In addition, as a consultant at McKinsey & Company, she advised the Gates Foundation and Teach First UK and led multiple due diligence processes for consumer and retail M&A clients. Heejae has earned a B.A. from Oxford University, an M.A. in International Development from the London School of Economics both with distinctive honors, and an MBA from Stanford Graduate School of Business, where she was an Arjay Miller Scholar. She has also been recognized as an Echoing Green Fellow, Stanford Social Innovation Fellow, Ashoka Changemaker, and Forbes 30 Under 30 for education.

yes.position: Founder & CEO | A2SV - Africa to Silicon Valley
yes.headline: CEO of A2SV - Africa to Silicon Valley | Founder on a Mission | Empowering Africa’s Top Tech Talent | Building Digital Solutions & Connecting Graduates with Global Leaders like Google & Bloomberg | Google-Backed
yes.summary:
If you’ve ever been to Africa, you know it’s the motherland of brilliant youth with immense potential to develop software and thrive in the digital global economy.

After working as a software engineer at Google and Palantir and as a machine learning engineer at Liftoff for 8 years in Silicon Valley, I decided to spend 6 months in Ethiopia training students—and that experience changed my life.

Despite the challenges these students face daily, the potential impact I saw in some of these young software developers was mind-blowing—and that’s why I founded A2SV.

A2SV is a nonprofit tech academy and incubator that upskills high-potential African university students, connects them to opportunities at the world’s top tech companies, and supports them in building digital solutions to address urgent challenges across Africa.

Here are our key accomplishments:

 In just 4 years, our students have received more than 60 job offers from companies like Google, Amazon, LinkedIn, Databricks, Palantir, and Bloomberg. In 2022, our students achieved a 70% acceptance rate in Google software engineering interviews, where the average acceptance rate is just 2%.

 In 2024, we organized the biggest hackathon on the African continent, focused on AI for impact. The A2SV Hackathon attracted over 4900 participants from 48 countries across Africa, fostering collaboration, learning, and innovation in solving real-world challenges.

 We are building a global talent marketplace to help our top-notch African software engineers connect with companies around the world, offering their skills for impactful projects.

How can you help?

I’m currently based in Africa, working on the ground with my team, and we’re looking for investors, donors, and strategic introductions.

 We urgently need more funding to sustain and scale our operations. We’re already backed by Google (twice) and Jeff Dean, but additional resources are critical as we continue to expand.

 We’re looking to connect with top tech companies, including Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, and Tesla, to secure more opportunities for our talented graduates.

 We’d love to connect with organizations interested in hiring world-class African software engineers.

To get involved, feel free to send me a LinkedIn message or email me at emre@a2sv.org.

Prior to Walmart, he served as a Policy Advisor for STEM Education, Innovation and Diversity in the White House during the Obama administration, leading efforts to expand access to high-quality education and job opportunities in science and technology.

Dr. Carr received a bachelor's degree and a Doctorate. in electrical engineering from Morgan State University, as well as a master's degree from the University of Maryland. He is a Bill and Melinda Gates Fellow and a member of the Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Inc.

Before joining the White House, Dr. Carr worked to advance federal funding and policymaking efforts in educational research, community development, workforce development, and diversity and inclusion. Most recently, he led federal efforts through the nation's public libraries and museums to support formal and informal education. Dr. Carr was recognized as the Corporate Philanthropy Leaders of the Year by the Council on Foundations in 2023 for his leadership, courage, integrity, and resilience in developing and executing the strategy and portfolio of the criminal justice focus area at Walmart.org's Center for Racial Equity.[

For over 17 years, Sarina Beges has worked for social change organizations in the areas of higher education, social impact, and philanthropy. At present, she serves as the Associate Director of Philanthropy Programs at the Aspen Institute where she curates and convenes the Aspen Philanthropy Group, a network of over 25 CEOs of private, public, and corporate foundations. She also works with community foundations leaders to make their work more effective through new research on business model innovation. 

Previous to the Aspen Institute,  Sarina served as the executive director of the Laura Arrillaga-Andreessen Foundation, which created educational content to enhance charitable giving. For nearly a decade, Sarina worked at Stanford University's Center on Democracy, Development, and the Rule of Law where she grew the reach and impact of a leading foreign policy research center.  In 2019, she helped produce the Philanthropy Innovation Summit – a gathering of over 300 philanthropic leaders – hosted by Stanford’s Center on Philanthropy and Civil Society.

Sarina started her social sector career at the Synergos Institute, a New York based non-profit organization committed to addressing issues of poverty and inequality worldwide. Sarina holds a master’s degree from the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies in Washington, DC and a bachelor’s degree from Boston University. She lives in Menlo Park, California with her husband and two daughters.

maybe.headline: CEO & Founder | Addressing Health Inequities for Black Women | Author, BLACK GIRLS BREATHING (available where books are sold) | Speaker
maybe.summary:
Jasmine Marie is a speaker, breathwork practitioner, author (Balance, an imprint of Hachette Book Group) and the CEO & Founder of black girls breathing. Her work is innovating the wellness, healthcare and research industry by making mental health services accessible to Black women while filling in the gaps of data and research available on this underserved and underrepresented demographic. Marie plans to impact 1 Million Black women and girls with her work by 2025.

She is a serial founder with a past life in global haircare brand marketing and an alum of NYU Stern. The impact and range of her work to date is expansive—ranging from underserved minority communities to stressed-out college students and executives. She’s brought her expertise to elite colleges such as Harvard Business School, Columbia University, Cornell University and her client list includes corporations such as Estée Lauder Companies, Under Armour, Capital One, Ford Motor Company, Facebook and Twitter. Marie has been featured in Oprah Magazine, Good Morning America, VOGUE, Forbes, Harper’s Baazar, Marie Claire, Glamour, Nylon Mag, Wall Street Journal and Black Enterprise to name a few.

For facilitation and speaking requests, please e-mail info@blackgirlsbreathing.com.

strengths: Strong commitment to equity, particularly for Black women and girls.
Experience as a CEO and founder, demonstrating entrepreneurial leadership.
Established speaker and author, which enhances public engagement and visibility.
gaps_or_concerns: Lacks direct experience in the technology sector, which is critical for Girls Who Code.
Limited experience with large-scale organizations and national reach.
ai_evaluation.detailed_rationale: Jasmine Marie brings a strong commitment to equity and has demonstrated leadership as the CEO and Founder of black girls breathing, focusing on health inequities for Black women. Her innovative mindset and public speaking skills could be beneficial, but the lack of relevant sector experience is a significant concern.
